cards.front: Define an open circuit in terms of its v-i relationship.
cards.back: An open circuit has i = 0 for all v. No current flows regardless of the voltage applied. Its v-i characteristic is the entire v-axis on the v-i plane.

cards.front: Define a short circuit in terms of its v-i relationship.
cards.back: A short circuit has v = 0 for all i. No voltage exists across it regardless of the current flowing. Its v-i characteristic is the entire i-axis on the v-i plane.

cards.front: What are the resistance and conductance of an open circuit?
cards.back: R = infinity (limiting sense), G = 0. The conductance is zero because i/v = 0/v = 0 for all nonzero v.

cards.front: What are the resistance and conductance of a short circuit?
cards.back: R = 0, G = infinity (limiting sense). The resistance is zero because v/i = 0/i = 0 for all nonzero i.

cards.front: State the five main dual pairs in circuit theory.
cards.back: v <-> i, R <-> G, series <-> parallel, KVL <-> KCL, open circuit <-> short circuit (and voltage source <-> current source).

cards.front: How do you geometrically find the dual of a v-i characteristic?
cards.back: Reflect the v-i characteristic about the 45-degree line (the line i = v). This swaps the roles of v and i, producing the dual element's characteristic.
If you solve a circuit and derive a result, the dual circuit's result is obtained by replacing every quantity with its dual. No re-derivation is needed.

cards.front: What is the dual of the series resistance formula R_total = R1 + R2?
cards.back: The dual is the parallel conductance formula: G_total = G1 + G2. Replace R with G and series with parallel.

cards.front: How much power does an open circuit absorb? A short circuit?
cards.back: Both absorb zero power. For an open circuit, p = vi = v * 0 = 0. For a short circuit, p = vi = 0 * i = 0.

cards.front: When does the duality principle NOT apply in its simple form?
cards.back: When the circuit is non-planar (cannot be drawn on a flat surface without crossing wires). For planar circuits, duality always applies.
